title: At their 130th Session, where will the International Olympic Committee decide to hold the 2024 and 2028 Olympics?
possible_answers: Paris in 2024, but Los Angeles not selected for 2028
Los Angeles in 2024, but Paris not selected for 2028,
preds: On Wednesday, the full IOC will award the 2024 Summer Games to Paris and the 2028 Games to Los Angeles.

The question supposed that the IOC will decide where to hold the 2024 and 2028 Olympics at their 130th session. But it seems like this might only happen at the 131st session? https://www.wikiwand.com/en/131st_IOC_Session The 130 session can be found here: https://www.olympic.org/130th-ioc-session

Macron is very keen for Paris to take the 2024 Olympic games as he declared Paris to be 'ready'. Yet, there remains a slight chance that LA will go first too.

If the deal as reported by media about Los Angeles agreeing to a 2028 bid is true, then it should be Paris 2024 and Los Angeles 2028 for sure. LA 28 seems to have been also approved by the City Council - http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-olympics-city-council-approves-20170811-story.html

Paris & LA are currently the only candidates being considered for these positions and LA announced its interest in 2028. Thus, so close to the announcement, it seems clear that 'Paris in 2024, Los Angeles in 2028' is the most likely option. I believe that 'Paris 2024, but Los Angeles not selected for 2028' is somewhat more likely than the remaining 3 options as if somewhere wanted to do a last minute bid, they'd likely choose 2028 as they would have longer to prepare if they were selected. The other 3 options are 1% rather than 0% due to the element of doubt introduced by potential factors that I have not foreseen.

Based on willingness of LA to host 2028, Paris to host 2024. While the probably that 1 drop out in favor of another country is non-zero, the probably of both is effectively 0. As both countries stated initial interest to host 2024, I'll assign a catch-all of 1% to both.

Paris and LA are frontrunners because they both have infrastructure in place but France is troubled by terrorism and the USA has Trump. Then there is the usual problem of bribery. It could plausibly be any of the first four scenarios

Believe the choice is mostly a done deal. But if it doesn't happen it will LA that gets the shaft.
It looks very much like a done deal now. bit reluctant to go 100% but believe chance of each of other results is now below 0.5% so going 100%.
The US will not be able to host these kind of international events at that time. The Olympics will return to mainland Europe within the period of 10-15 years.

Has anyone taken into account that they could announce it NOT at their 130th Session?
Los Angeles has agreed to host the 2028 games, so the announcement in September is just a formality now.

Los Angeles was confirmed as the venue for the 2028 Olympic and Paralympic games, leaving Paris—the only other city in the running for 2024—free to play host sooner. Both had coveted the earlier date but LA apparently conceded the spot after being offered an extra $1.8bn in funding. Each city has held the games twice already: Paris in 1900 and 1924

Going all in for the compromise due to some recent New York Times reporting. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/31/sports/olympics/los-angeles-2028-summer-olympics.html?emc=edit_na_20170731&nl=breaking-news&nlid=69656099&ref=cta

Paris is a shoe-in for 2024 (I think), but the 2028 question is not that easy to settle. At the minimum, the City Council will have to agree, and perhaps the financial backing has to be secured (although one imagines this can also be done after the IOC's Sep 13 decision). Moreover, there might be political costs for Garcetti giving up 2024 without a fight. Some influential Angelenos may well prefer to fight for 2024 now (despite the slim chance) and, if they lose, apply for 2028 afterwards. Given that the infrastructure is largely in place, the cost of waiting is pretty low.  Of course, Garcetti can still pull this out, getting a Council vote in the remaining 6 weeks and promising to settle the financial guarantees later. In fact, given what he said after the last IOC session, this is the overwhelming probability - but not as large as 97 percent...

http://aroundtherings.com/site/A__60971/Title__Top-Story-Replay-IOC-Negotiates-for-2028-Olympics/292/Articles "A move for Los Angeles to 2028 will require a review by the Los Angeles City Council and the California state legislature, which has said it would back a $250 million guarantee for the 2024 Games. Changes to make those guarantees stand for 2028 would be needed. "No date has been set for the public review of the revised Los Angeles bid plan, pending completion of the talks with the IOC. But that should happen in the coming weeks, as the IOC wants the question settled before the IOC vote scheduled at the Session in Lima Sept. 13.  "If an agreement cannot be reached, the IOC will only select a 2024 host city. "While IOC President Thomas Bach indicated last week that both Paris and Los Angeles would be in play for either 2024 or 2028, behind the scenes there is a tacit belief that the IOC supports Paris first with Los Angeles favored as the 2028 host.

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/18/opinion/trump-muslim-ban-supreme-court.html?emc=edit_th_20170718&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=77825025 This article describes how the Trump administration has created more bureaucratic red-tape and hoops for people from Muslim countries to have to deal with in order to get visas to enter the US, mentioning a student robotics team which was denied visas to attend a competition here until there was public uproar and Trump personally intervened.  I think that visa issues would hang over the LA bid like a dark thundercloud and will cause the IOC to give the 2028 Olympics to LA--because a new administration would be in place in the US by then, and hopefully these processes would have eased.

However, the committee is widely expected to award the 2024 Games to Paris and the 2028 Olympics to Los Angeles."

LA has had it too often, Paris gets sympathy vote, so favouring the option which includes Paris but not LA.

Concerns about the Paris bid include 
-30% of the land for the Olympic Village has not been purchased 
-other concerns about the Paris budget. . . . another $3.19 billion is needed for infrastructure and other Olympic-related expenditures. Security, overlay and temporary infrastructure costs may be understated, but could be offset by potential expenditure reductions in other areas, 
-pollution in the Seine for the triathlon and marathon swimming competitions. Concerns about the LA bid include: 
-the transportation network to 2 venues 
-the cost of a possible renovation of the velodrome may exceed $66m 
-a lack of certainty over the funding of the International Broadcast Center 
-risk of reliance on privately owned venues I note that it is thought that the IOC favors Paris  It is not a "done deal" yet (as I had thought) that the 2028 host will be selected now, as well.

Even the Euro-centric IOC will have concerns about security in the 4 Euorpean cites being considered for 2024, so the LA in 2024 options should rank high. 
Giving "none of the above" higher probability than Paris is simply playing the field. Giving Paris/LA higher prob than Paris/other recognizes that US has not hosted for quite awhile
Readjusting according to the news on Paris and LA regarding their will to have the Olympics in 2028 if they should not get it in 2024; and according to betting markets for 2024: Paris 93 vs. LA 7.
https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Paris-stuns-Olympic-Committee Paris has said it is only interested in hosting the 2024 games while Los Angeless has been more open about the 2028 Olympics.

http://www.ocregister.com/2017/07/05/ioc-report-la-paris-are-worthy-vastly-different-2024-olympics-hosts-2/ “The Los Angeles and Paris presentations to the IOC next Tuesday and Wednesday will be overshadowed by the IOC membership’s expected approval at the same meetings of IOC president Thomas Bach’s plan to simultaneously award the 2024 and 2028 Games. The joint-awarding plan was approved by the IOC executive committee last month.
. . . 
“ . . . IOC leadership favors a deal in which Paris would be awarded the 2024 Games, with the world returning to Southern California four years later for a third Olympics in Los Angeles, according to international sports officials and consultants who have worked with the IOC and are familiar with the IOC’s inner workings.
. . . 
“Eight cities have withdrawn bids for the last two available Olympic Games, with no viable host city candidate for the 2028 Games appearing on the horizon. Four cities — Boston, Rome, Budapest and Hamburg — pulled out of the 2024 bidding, with Toronto officials deciding against even entering the race.
~~~~~~~
COMMENTS:
1) Concerns about the Paris bid include
-30% of the land for the Olympic Village has not been purchased
-other concerns about the Paris budget. . . . another $3.19 billion is needed for infrastructure and other Olympic-related expenditures. Security, overlay and temporary infrastructure costs may be understated, but could be offset by potential expenditure reductions in other areas,
-pollution in the Seine for the triathlon and marathon swimming competitions. 2) Concerns about the LA bid include:
-the transportation network to 2 venues 
-the cost of a possible renovation of the velodrome may exceed $66m
-a lack of certainty over the funding of the International Broadcast Center 
-risk of reliance on privately owned venues  3) I’m going to adjust my forecast.  I think that I mis-read the findings of the IOC report:  there was not a 15% difference in the points awarded by the IOC, only in the local support. 4). I note that it is thought that the IOC favors Paris and that it is not a "done deal" yet (as I had thought) that the 2028 host will be selected now, as well.

Basically following crowd and general knowledge for first stab. LA has stated they want games and infrastructure under way for NFL but 24 is quick so more likely for 28 and low chance neither. If Paris doesn't get 24 enthusiasm cools. Betting the field above the either or until have more info.

https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2017/07/05/ioc-commission-2024-olympic-bids-los-angeles-and-paris/452364001/ "Olympic bids from Los Angeles and Paris to host the 2024 Games received praise . . . in a report released Wednesday, . . . [which]  included new polling numbers on support of each bid that show Los Angeles with a 15% advantage.
. . . 
" . . .  the IOC [is] set to meet next week to vote on a recommendation to award the 2024 and 2028 Olympics simultaneously.
. . . 
"In addition to the evaluation of the bid and technical analysis of the cities’ plans, the report included recent polling that showed Los Angeles garnering more support and less opposition to the Olympics.
. . . 
“With no permanent venues to build and overwhelming public support, LA 2024 can concentrate on putting the best assets of the top global sports and entertainment market to work for the Olympic and Paralympic Movements,” said Casey Wasserman, LA 2024 chairman, in a statement. “We think that makes Los Angeles an ideal Olympic city and an ideal partner for the IOC right now.”
. . . 
"The report noted Los Angeles’ venue inventory exceeded the Games’ needs. "The commission noted as a challenge the implementation of a strong transport plan between Los Angeles’ four planned sports parks, saying it would “require significant efforts to manage and reduce traffic.” And it highlighted awareness of Paralympic sport as a challenge in the United States. "Among challenges the commission noted for Paris is the clean-up of the River Siene, where it plans to host triathlon and marathon swimming. "It estimated the security threat would be very low to low for the Games and Olympic-related travel, but it estimated the threat to the cities as low for Los Angeles and medium for Paris. "The report is intended to guide IOC members as they head toward a vote on Sept. 13 in Lima. What that vote will be for is likely to be decided next week when the IOC hosts a technical briefing for both bids.  During those meetings, IOC members will vote on a unanimous recommendation the executive board made last month to award the 2024 and 2028 Olympics at the same time, with one going to Los Angeles and one going to Paris. "The IOC has not outlined how the process would progress from there, including what negotiations it might have with the bid cities to consider accepting a 2028 Games.  In light of challenges the IOC has faced in bidding – more cities have dropped out of the last two cycles than have remained to the vote – president Thomas Bach is eager to address a process that “produces too many losers.” "Bids from Los Angeles and Paris “have put the Olympic movement in a win-win situation,” Baumann said in the report, “with very little to separate the two projects.”

The IOC's decisions are almost always highly political and tied to the prevailing global political and economic trends of the day.   In light of Macron's election victory and reinvigoration of French politics and image on the global stage,  I imagine the IOC will want to affiliate itself with the Macron brand.  As for Los Angeles, I wonder if some key members of the IOC wish they could vote to re-open candidates for 2028 rather than award Los Angeles, to signal discomfort for Trump's anti-globalist policies.
Not sure if I should even forecast this cause it seems all but confirmed.

https://newsahead.com/los-angeles-and-paris-to-host-2024-and-2028-olympics/ A proposal to award the 2024 and 2028 Games to Los Angeles and Paris - the only candidates left in the race for 2024 - was "unanimously" approved by the IOC Executive Board in June.

LA has given the IOC a means not only to award Paris the 2024 games, but to gain good global citizen points in so doing. By offering to step back if the IOC will magnanimously help fund children's sports in an American metropolis with a significant population of "underprivileged youth," the City of Angels has given itself extra time to get that new football stadium up and running, as well as to lock down a few more corporate sponsors to ensure the profitability of the Games. Having held the last summer Olympiad to leave its host city in the black, the organizing committee has a standard to meet.

* Other cities withdrew their bid.
* Betting/predictions markets give Paris 80 percent, LA 20 percent for 2024... after all I could read, this seems a little overrated for Paris, so I would say it is 75 Paris, 25 LA.
* Odds for not selecting 2028 and 2024 at a time: Will be clear on 11/12 July meeting of IOC, but - so far - I would guess that it is fairly likely they will do so --- after having an unanimous vote of the Executive Committee in favor of the linkage in June in Lausanne. I guess it is 90 percent they will have the linkage, and 10 they will not.
* It follows that the city not selected for 2024 must be the one selected for 2028. Doing the math leads to my forecast:
Paris in 2024, Los Angeles in 2028: 67%
* 0,90*0,75 = 0,67
Los Angeles in 2024, Paris in 2028: 23%
* 0,90*0,25 = 0,225
Paris in 2024, but Los Angeles not selected for 2028: 8%
* 0,10*0,75 = 0,075
Los Angeles in 2024, but Paris not selected for 2028: 2%
* 0,10*0,25 = 0,025
None of the above: 0%

I think Paris is an easy favorite for 2024 for a few reasons. First is political, on the global stage Macron is more popular than trump and in my experience the IOC plays politics with its decisions. Second is the historic nature of Paris 2024 as the centenary of the last time Paris hosted the games. Finally, Paris has been a consistent runner up in the last few cycles and the IOC tends to weigh runner up cities a little more heavily. Regarding 2028, the IOC has decided to award both 2024 and 2028 at the same time (see link) so I think it's likely that LA, as the only serious bidder other than Paris, will get the 2028 games. https://www.olympic.org/news/ioc-executive-board-charts-the-course-for-future-olympic-games

Definitely Paris in 2024, for reasons most other forecasters have discussed already. As for 2028, 50/50 with regards to Los Angeles. On one hand, they have the infrastructure in place already, and with the new NFL Rams stadium being built, will be more than able to accommodate. Plus California, and Los Angeles in particular, has a tendency of showing a disdain for fiscal responsibility...also, more and more countries that previously would have bid (i.e. Middle Eastern, Asia, Europe) are facing fiscal headwinds, such as low oil prices for the Middle East, and a general lack of interest in incurring the debt and tax payers' wrath necessary to build new facilities in the case of Asia and Europe, respectively. However, President Trump and his politics are sure to be a deterrent to the IOC. Hence the 50/50.
I think Paris is in, however Los Angeles, less so. An upset would not be surprising either...
Considering the now outrageous cost to host the games and what happens to the venues after the games, I can't see any responsible level headed government bidding to host the games.

Paris seems set on 2024, while LA has said its not fixed on a particular year, hence the outcome seems straightforward. The IOC would also prefer this result to gain certainty. The only possible spanner in the works might be the IOC's own internal procedures that need to be changed in time for September in order for two host cities being confirmed at once.
